abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Ethiopia Health Sector
            Development Program were as follows: outcomes were
            moderately satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            significant, the Bank performance was unsatisfactory, and
            the Borrower performance was moderately satisfactory. Some
            lessons learned included: There is a need to synchronize the
            infrastructure, human resource and support systems within
            the accelerated expansion of Primary Health Care (PHC),
            paying due attention to all components of the Health
            Services Extension Program (HSEP); regions should prioritize
            making existing health facilities (hospitals, health centers
            and health posts) fully operational through rehabilitation
            and provision of appropriately trained health workers,
            equipment and medicines; central human resources development
            must be strengthened, particularly in its strategic and
            stewardship capacity, and it is urgent to establish
            incentive schemes (in addition to the standard civil-service
            provisions) to retain staff, especially at outlying
            stations, and to ensure continuing service delivery for
            disadvantaged populations; efforts are still needed in the
            area of procurement and distribution, human resource
            availability, rational drug use, budget allocation and
            logistics to ensure regular supply of quality and affordable
            drug supply to all levels; and there is a need to build
            sufficient flexibility into a sector program so that the
            efficacy of investment is not contingent upon the
            involvement of other donors.
